patches.reasoning: The prior knowledge section is designed to ensure pupils have a foundational understanding of Roman Britain and its influence on Britain.

value: The Romans ruled Britain for around 400 years.
Roman roads connected towns and cities across Britain.
Roman Britain was part of the Roman Empire.
Roman soldiers built forts and walls for protection.
The Roman Empire included many modern countries.

patches.reasoning: Key learning points focus on the transition period from Roman to post-Roman Britain.

value: The Roman army left Britain around AD 410.
Britain was left without Roman protection and governance.
New groups like the Saxons began to settle in Britain.
Many Roman structures and roads remained and influenced Britain.
Archaeologists study artefacts to understand this period.

patches.reasoning: Misconceptions are addressed to prevent misunderstandings about Roman Britain's end and its historical context.

value.misconception: The Romans left Britain because they were defeated.
value.description: The Romans left Britain due to pressures in other parts of the Empire, not defeat in Britain.

value.misconception: Britain became part of another empire immediately after the Romans.
value.description: After the Romans left, Britain was not immediately part of another empire.

value.misconception: All Roman structures disappeared when they left.
value.description: Many Roman structures remained and were used by later inhabitants.

patches.reasoning: Keywords help pupils understand the specific vocabulary related to the lesson on Roman Britain's end.

value.definition: A large empire that ruled over Britain and much of Europe.
A person who studies the past by examining artefacts.
A group of people who settled in Britain after the Romans.
An object made or used by people in the past.
A strong building used for defence by the Roman army.
